sections.title: Business Succession Planning
sections.content: Every business owner needs a succession plan outlining what happens to the business if you die, become disabled, or want to retire. Options include transferring to family members, selling to partners or employees, or selling to third parties. Start planning early to maximize value and minimize disruption.

points.title: Family Succession
points.description: Transferring business to children or other family members through gifts or sales.

points.title: Management Buyout
points.description: Selling to key employees or management team members.

points.title: Third-Party Sale
points.description: Selling to external buyers, often the most lucrative option for valuable businesses.

sections.title: Buy-Sell Agreements
sections.content: These legal contracts specify how business ownership transfers upon death, disability, or retirement. They provide certainty and can help fund business succession.

sections.title: Tax Considerations for Business Owners
sections.content: Business interests may qualify for special tax treatment. Consider entity structure (LLC, corporation, partnership) and use of trusts or other vehicles to minimize estate taxes. Life insurance can provide liquidity for estate taxes or business continuation.

sections.title: Plan Your Business Succession
steps: Determine your preferred succession option (family, employees, or sale)
Create or update your business succession plan
Implement buy-sell agreements with business partners
Review life insurance needs for business continuation and estate taxes

sections.title: Start Planning Early
sections.content: Business succession planning takes time and should begin years before you plan to exit. Early planning allows you to maximize business value and implement tax-efficient strategies.
